repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
don't think this change is needed? the line just below checks `opts.signs and ...` which suggests that nil `opts.signs` is expected and supported.

your other changes LGTM
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,6 +1535,10 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if not opts.signs then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
Yes, I plan to remove `opts.signs` from other places after applying the argument validation by those 3 lines.
The reason is that when new code is added, we don't need to always have `opts.signs` in each similar statement. And sometimes, people might forget to add and might trigger the same problem again.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,6 +1535,10 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if not opts.signs then
+      return
+    end

@@ -1535,6 +1535,10 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if not opts.signs then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
It's not fully correct to use `if not opts.signs`, when I set it as true, the same error will occur.
It might need type checking. For example, `if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table'`.

Go further step, the document says `signs` could be boolean value and the global default value is `true`. However, if the default value of `opts` in `M.handlers.signs#show` function is changed to `global_diagnostic_options`, the same error will occur.

Therefore, I am not sure if the `signs` is wrongly designed to accept boolean value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,6 +1535,10 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if not opts.signs then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
The old code was handling the case where `opts.signs` was not provided. If `signs=true` and the handler is called, then this handler should make default decisions, not skip itself entirely.

So maybe this change makes sense (and do this just below 1532))?:

```suggestion
    opts.signs = opts.signs or {}
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
Yes, I partially agree that when signs=true, it should not fully skipped. However, the code related to access signs's keys by assuming signs is a table should be updated to validate type firstly. 

For example, if signs=ture, the below code won't have chance to pickup the default value 10 for priority, instead, it will fail due to the same error:

`local priority = opts.signs and opts.signs.priority or 10 `  

Test code:
```
local opts = {signs = true}
local priority = opts.signs and opts.signs.priority or 10
```

Output of "source test.lua"
`E5113: Error while calling lua chunk: ... test.lua:2: attempt to index field 'signs' (a boolean value)`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
The below code might be expected and workable
```
is_signs_table = type(opts.signs) == 'table'
local priority = is_signs_table and opts.signs.priority or 10
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
No this is not needed. In `vim.diagnostic.show` we resolve the set of options so that when an option is set to `true` it is replaced by a default table.

The handlers should ALWAYS receive a table for `opts`. If they don't, it's a bug. Handlers do not need to check the type of `opts` or `opts.signs`. If they're getting something besides a table that's a bug, but not a bug in the handler.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body:
OK, I see now. It should not be a bug of `diagnostic.lua` since I re-write the handlers sign and virtual_text in my configuration code where has no same logic as `diagnostic.lua` did in the function `resolve_optional_value`.

I will fix it in my own configuration code then. The bug ticket could be cancelled.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1535,8 +1535,12 @@ M.handlers.signs = {
       return
     end
 
+    if type(opts.signs) ~= 'table' then
+      return
+    end

comment_data.body: I've already explained that this isn't necessary. `opts.signs` will be either a table or `nil`. So the existing `if opts.signs` check is sufficient.
I am trying to use this commit https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34483/commits/6804f62cc961afd9bb6a4125274ec3ee87d3c4e0 but I didn't manage to remove old commits.
`git rebase -i HEAD~11`, then `drop` all but the one commit. Then force-push the PR.

comment_regular_data.body: This is not the right fix. If you are passing `signs = false` in opts then the signs handler shouldnt be called *at all*. The bug is that the handler is still being called, not that the type is incorrect.

> If you are passing signs = false in opts then the signs handler shouldnt be called at all.

But as I said, if `signs = true`, then the handler will be called, and the error will occur also.

> > If you are passing signs = false in opts then the signs handler shouldnt be called at all.
> 
> But as I said, if `signs = true`, then the handler will be called, and the error will occur also.

No, when `signs = true` the option is resolved to a table https://github.com/gpanders/neovim/blob/286371b4d22a0abd3c037823ae14ef7ce8ba06b6/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L2159

If you can reproduce an error when `signs = true` then that is a separate bug. The handlers should always received a *resolved* table where each option is itself a table, not a boolean. So the handlers themselves DO NOT need to check if `opts` is a table: it always should be.

For now, I suggest just adding this after the existing validation:

    vim.validate('opts.signs', (opts and opts or {}).signs, 'table', true)

That at least clarifies the expectations here. If there is some bug in a caller, that can be addressed separately. Or there is a bug in your plugins.

> For now, I suggest just adding this after the existing validation:
> 
> ```
> vim.validate('opts.signs', (opts and opts or {}).signs, 'table', true)
> ```
> 
> That at least clarifies the expectations here. If there is some bug in a caller, that can be addressed separately. Or there is a bug in your plugins.

OK, I can use another PR to do so.
Not real bug in the code of diagnostics. The error is triggered by the customized diagnostics handlers which do not well-handled the boolean values configured for opts.signs

> That at least clarifies the expectations here. If there is some bug in a caller, that can be addressed separately. Or there is a bug in your plugins.

I didn't manage to solve the failure in this build
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/15737543752/job/44354197029?pr=34483

Any suggestion?
You can't force-push a closed PR; that will break Github. I'm afraid you'll have to open a new PR now.

> you'll have to open a new PR



> You can't force-push a closed PR; that will break Github. I'm afraid you'll have to open a new PR now.

It's not my intention to force push to the close PR. My understanding was to force to the branch for the PR.

`git push origin HEAD:34482 --force`

But the result is unexpected.
With the checked out branch, just `git push -f` should do. (Pro tip: the `gh` CLI makes opening and working with pull requests much easier.)

> You can't force-push a closed PR; that will break Github. I'm afraid you'll have to open a new PR now.

Yes, it was really one mistake.
